description.narrative: Denna beredning avser ett stöd till UNDPs Strategi för Water & Oceans Governance Programme (WOGP) 2014-17. Totalt avtalsbelopp med Sida för perioden är 121 miljoner kronor och hela strategin är på 148 miljoner USD (1 milijard kronor) inklusive andra givares, främst GEFs stöd, men exclusive regeringars medfinansiering . Verksamheternas fokus ligger fortsatt på stödjandet av vattensektorreformer och stärkandet av sektorförvaltning (governance) vad gäller vattenresursförvaltning, dricksvattenförsörjning, sanitet samt hygien genom etablerade mekanismer, kanaler och program såsom WGF, GoAL-WaSH och Shared Waters Partnership. Sidas bedömning är att planerade verksamheter och aktiviteter kommer att kunna genomföras som planerat och i enlighet med uppsatta mål och förväntade resultat i UNDPs strategi. Den valda finansieringsformen är ett icke-öronmärkt programbaserat (PBA) gåvobistånd. Koordinering sker dels genom ett årligt möte samt i direkt dialog med UNDP. Uppföljning kommer, förutom genom årsgenomgångar, att ske i form av bedömning av narrativa och finansiella rapporter och annat relevant material som tas fram av programmet.

The UNDP Water Governance Program (WGP) aims towards assisting countries improve water governance, building capacities and mainstreaming effective water resources management, water supply and sanitation policy at different levels - local, national, regional and global.The support includes earlier UNDP CapNet programme.

The UNDP Water and Ocean Governance Programme (WOGP) is an umbrella programme composed of a set of coordinated projects and programs. Each project and program has activities at either local, national, regional or global level. The objective with WOGP is to help countries achieve integrated, climate-resilient, sustainable and equitable management of water and ocean resources, and universal access to safe water supply and sanitation, through improved water and ocean governance, in turn contributing to poverty alleviation and human development.
The WOGP is one of the main global mechanisms contributing to the delivery of the freshwater and ocean aspects of UNDP's main Strategic Plan. It addresses the challenges related to the Sustainable Development Goals SDG 6 and SDG 14. The focus on governance and collective efforts towards protecting freshwater and marine resources, and delivering related services, connects WOGP with the broad approach of the 2030 Agenda.
Sidas funding of WOGP is not earmarked to any specific project or activity. Instead, UNDP maintains that Sida's support is critical for the cross-programme knowledge management, capacity development and coordinated policy advocacy and thought leadership organised through UNDPs Global Policy Network. This cross-programme management and coordination is facilitated through the delivery mechanisms of the UNDP-SIWI Water Governance Facility, hosted by the Stockholm International Water Institute (SIWI). The capacity building programme International Capacity Development Network for Sustainable Water Management (Cap-Net) is hosted by the Global Water Partnership Organization (GWPO).

sector.narrative: Water sector policy and administrative management

tag.narrative: 14.1 - By 2025, prevent and significantly reduce marine pollution of all kinds, in particular from land-based activities, including marine debris and nutrient pollution.
14.1 - Till 2025 förebygga och avsevärt minska alla slags föroreningar i havet, i synnerhet från landbaserad verksamhet, inklusive marint skräp och tillförsel av näringsämnen.

14.2 - By 2020, sustainably manage and protect marine and coastal ecosystems to avoid significant adverse impacts, including by strengthening their resilience, and take action for their restoration in order to achieve healthy and productive oceans.

14.2 - Senast 2020 förvalta och skydda marina och kustnära ekosystem på ett hållbart sätt för att undvika betydande negativa konsekvenser, bland annat genom att stärka deras motståndskraft, samt vidta åtgärder för att återställa dem i syfte att uppnå friska och produktiva hav.

6.3 - By 2030, improve water quality by reducing pollution, eliminating dumping and minimizing release of hazardous chemicals and materials, halving the proportion of untreated wastewater and substantially increasing recycling and safe reuse globally.

6.3 - Till 2030 förbättra vattenkvaliteten genom att minska föroreningar, stoppa dumpning och minimera utsläpp av farliga kemikalier och material, halvera andelen obehandlat avloppsvatten och väsentligt öka återvinningen och en säker återanvändning globalt.
6.5 - By 2030, implement integrated water resources management at all levels, including through transboundary cooperation as appropriate.
6.5 - Senast 2030 genomföra en integrerad förvaltning av vattenresurser på alla nivåer, när så är lämpligt genom gränsöverskridande samarbete.

description.narrative:
Sida provides non-earmarked programme funding, which means that Sida's contribution is not directed towards any specific activity/result. Furthermore, Sida's support contstitutes only about 5% of the total budget of the WOGP (the main funding sources is the GEF). As such, Sida can not claim that our funding has enabled any specific, single result. Instead, Sida can claim that our funding contributes to some extent to all the results achieved.
The UNDP Water and Ocean Governance Programme (WOGP) has during the last 12-18 months delivered a number of results. These results relates mainly to two goals in the global strategy for environment 2018-2022. Below are some examples of the results, listed under these two goals respectively:
GOAL: Stronger protection and restoration, and sustainable management and use of marine, coastal and freshwater ecosystems, biodiversity, natural resources and ecosystem services:
- Launching of the SDG6 Global Acceleration Framework, coordinated by UN-Water. This framework, setup to support work by the UN, aims at accelerating and scale-up SDG6- related activities at country level.
- Within the GEF-UNDP Global Marine Commodities Project and its activities in Ecuador, recovery of stocks of small pelagic fish species have been noticed (end 2020). Species such as tuna, mackerel, herring, scad and achoveta have been monitored for some time and due to improved stocks management, supported by the WOGP project, increased stocks have been measured. All theses species were previously overfished but are now harvested within sustainable limits.
- The WOGP contributed to the UN's World Water Development Report 2021, which is a global normative publication. This latest report focussed on Valuing Water, i.e. emphasising and recognising the multiple values of water.
- Through the programme Partnership in Environmental Management for the Seas of East Asia (PEMSEA), integrated coastal management (ICM) has continued to be applied in coastal zones across East Asia. ICM has through the programme continously been mainstreamed and applied in local and national institutions, policies and laws.
- In 2020 a set of sectoral checklists were produced on Water interaction to consider for NDC enhancement, to assist countries with integration of water into NDC plans and their implementation.
- UNDP's Source-to-Sea platform continues to play a significant convening role for contributions toward the upcoming UN Ocean Conference, now scheduled for June 2022.
- The large capacity building programme Cap-Net has during the period e.g. trained around 5 500 water stakeholders; reached 163 countries; invested 1.2 MUSD and leveraged 2.8 MUSD
GOAL: Cleaner water and oceans, reduced emissions of pollutants and reduced littering:
- The programme Governance, Accountability and Learning for Water Sustainability (GoAL-WaterS) has in India, in 2021, supported some 41 women grassroot stewards with local water management projects. The projects were selected through a call for proposals process.
- The challenge fund Ocean Innovation Challenge (OIC) was launched in 2020. Of over 600 applications, 8 proposals were finally approved and funded, and have now started implementation. This first call of the OIC focussed on marine pollution (SDG target 14.1). The OIC is also recieving additional financial support from Sida, in a separate contribution specifically for he OIC.
COVID Like most other organisations, UNDP and its WOGP has had to change its working routines during the pandemic. In-person meetings and travel have been put on hold or held through virtual means. Projects within the WOGP have nevetheless continued, with on-line training, on-line launch of the OIC challenge fund, production and on-line dissemination of checklists and policy advice, etc. WOGP reports however that many incountry project partners have suffered personal and economic losses. In 2020, the UN was supposed to hold its second conference on the Ocean (the first, in 2017, was co-hosted by Sweden). Due to the covid-19 pandemic, this conference has now been postponed until 2022.
The abovementioned results are just a selection of results achieved by the WOGP during the past 12-18 months. The full set of results are described in UNDP's annual report to Sida on progress during the 1 Jan 2020 - 30 April 2021 period. The reason for the report being longer than 12 months is that a balance of funds remained at the end of 2020, which was used for activities in 2021. And rather than reporting on those 2021 activities in a separate Annual Report later in 2022, UNDP has included these 2021 activities in the 2020 Annual Report.
The abovementioned report is the last annual report for this contribution. A final programme report is due 31 December 2021, covering the whole 2014-2021 period
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

sida:strategy.sida:title: Sustainable environment, climate, oceans and use of natural resources 2018-2022
